creator: smgoodmn
title: Custom Kitchen Sound Identifier
materials_required: KEYESTUDIO 16x16 Dot Matrix LED Display for Arduino
description: This project creates a real-time system for identifying and visualizing common kitchen sounds using Support-Vector Machine classification. It uses a laptop for audio sampling and classification, and an Arduino with a dot matrix display for visualization. It can be used to assist deaf or hard-of-hearing individuals, or adapted for other sound identification contexts.
steps: Collect kitchen sound samples using the provided Jupyter notebook (CollectSamples.ipynb).
Copy the CollectSamples.ipynb notebook to your working Jupyter Notebook directory and open it.
Run each cell of the CollectSamples.ipynb notebook, paying attention to the notes. Create an empty directory to store your samples.
Edit the SAMPLES_LOCATION variable in the notebook to match your empty directory's location.
Add or remove sounds to the SOUND_LABELS variable in the correct format.
Evaluate the "Sample Recording" cell to start sample collection. Follow the prompts and record 5-10 samples of each sound.
Input "x" to exit the execution when finished.
(Optional) Check the WAV data of individual files in the "Quick Sound Visualization" cell to make sure you captured all desired information.
Wire the Arduino and LED matrix according to the provided diagram.
Open "arduino_listener.ino" using the Arduino IDE and upload it to the Leonardo.
Prepare icons for each target sound as byte arrays using the Dot2Piconline tool or similar.
Replace unneeded icons in the "arduino_listening.ino" code with your custom icons, adding comments to describe them.
Upload the modified code to the Arduino.
Copy the FullPipeline.ipynb notebook to your working Jupyter Notebook directory and open it.
Run each cell of the FullPipeline.ipynb notebook, stopping at the "Load the Training Data" cell.
Edit the SAMPLES_LOCATION_ROOT and SAMPLES_DIR_NAME variables to point to your sample directory.
Continue running each cell, stopping at the "Messaging Arduino" cell.
Define the serial port for Arduino communication in the PORT_DEF variable.
Reopen Arduino IDE. In places where you made changes to the icons, make a note of the letter next to the array value, but DO NOT change it.
Returning to the "Messaging Arduino" cell, change the labels in the self.sounds dictionary to match the labels used in recording your samples, ensuring correspondence with the noted letters.
Run the main function in the FullPipeline.ipynb notebook to start the classification and sound identification process.
Create a housing for the system, such as using LEGO bricks, ensuring proper placement of the Arduino, wiring, and LED matrix display.
